name: GJ 3779
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 3779 Exoplanetary System

GJ 3779 is a star with 0.27 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.28 times its radius. It is located 44.85 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 3779 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

GJ 3779 b

GJ 3779 b was discovered by the Calar Alto Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.02 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, GJ 3779.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.07, which means that when GJ 3779 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.02 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.03. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of GJ 3779 b is 8.00 times the mass of Earth. At 8.00 Earth masses, GJ 3779 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 3779, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Calar Alto Observatory.
